comments:
The API doc for Keystroke.getInstance() says that it will throw a ParseException if the given formal string representation could not be parsed. However, I have found that Strings like 'Ctrl+Shi' throw an IAE rather than a ParseException. The exception is actually coming from:

Caused by: java.lang.IllegalArgumentException: Unrecognized formal key name: SHI
at org.eclipse.jface.bindings.keys.SWTKeyLookup.formalKeyLookup(SWTKeyLookup.java:268)
at org.eclipse.jface.bindings.keys.KeyStroke.getInstance(KeyStroke.java:146)

I don't know if this is intended but it means callers need to catch ParseException and IAE if they want to deal with badly formed key strokes.
